Not a complaint, but constructive criticism:
You said MR is interesting in its own right in order to "defend" your failures.
You did however NOT say that the commercial ferrofluids are actually the "better ones" if better is defined by "useability in applications". These spikes are surface instabilities that are to be avoided for applications! The commercial ferrofluids try to maximize how strong the ferrofluids are while still staying stable without any surface instabilities. You could have measured how fast they move around in a magnetic field compared to your FF in order to find out how strong the magnetic properties are.
Instead of saying this, you just "defined" the value of a FF by the size of its spikes.
It definitely is the more interesting and artistic version of a FF, but you should have reasearched WHY the commercial FF have less spikes instead of boosting your ego.

English is not my first language and I did not want to complain, I just wanted to remind everyone to keep up the scientific integrity. I just found it weird that large spikes are good when in practical applications it is the opposite but in case of a failure (your MR) you felt the urge to say something positive about the MR. You should say something positive about the non-spiky FF, too!

The best conditions and ingridients to get the smallest nano particles (10-100 nm) of Fe3O4(magnetite) and the best magnetic properties, according to the research made by russian scientists that i've found online are:

FeCl3-FeCl2 ratio 2:1, concentration 0.5% by mass in water.
NH4 solution in water, concentration 2% by volume.
They used Triton X 100 detergent (surface-active substance ), didnt say how and when...
Adding drops of ammonium solution while stirring 15 min.
Separation with magnet.
Cleaning in distilled water.
(https://www.science-education.ru/ru/article/view?id=10559)

Hey so this is almost certainly not the most efficient way to make ferrofluid, but the other day I was turning a piece of steel on a lathe with a live center at one end. The live center was kind of broken and so it rubbed against the steel, which must have abraded off some really fine pieces of metal particles and also magnetized them. These particles got caught in suspension with the oil I was using to lubricate the cutting and made a very effective ferrofluid. I thought this result was interesting and felt like sharing it with this community.

IMO, the coolest parts of ferrofluid are its potential real life applications. Most of these are really futuristic, but they could be really useful too. One example is that if you prepared the magnetite in an extremely (unrealistically) large quantity and applied it to an oil spill, a magnet could be used to clean up the spill. This obviously isn't super realistic atm but I thought the idea was cool. Also, being able to control Nano particles like this apparently has some serious applications in medicine. Not gonna pretend that I completely understand how this would work, but I heard something about how it could lead to a potential cure for Alzheimers and brain cancer.

In DisneyWorld’s Animal Kingdom, there is a ride based around the Avatar movie called Flight of Passage. In the waiting line, you pass through the lab from the movie. In it, there are little “creatures” from the planet, and today I learned that they’re ferrofluid in water! The little black blobs would suddenly turn spiky and zoom around the edges of the glass boxes they were in, and then melt back into blobs. Ok, I’m sure this is a border line stupid question, but isn’t that what the internet is ultimately all about? Gold panning is a hobby of mine and one of the side products you end up with is mineral magnetite. It’s obviously a long way away from being “nano” sized, but is pretty fine grained. Most sand would look very chunky compared to it. But how much larger is this than the nano magnetite you’re creating? Is it even the same thing? Could you create a ferrofluid using it as a starting point? Can I ask more questions that further complicate any chance of a coherent answer? The answer to that last one is certainly “yes”, so I’ll just step back and see where these questions lead.

Just a thought, and someone else has probably suggested this, but if you are concerned with oxidation have you considered a heavier than air gas barrier?

For lots of reactions something like CO2 is cheap and easy to come by (or produce) and will fill the top of your reaction vessel and sit there happily enough. With a constant feed it will displace the air and effectively seal the reaction. That probably wouldn't work for this, I expect it would react with ammonia and interfere with your results, but argon is widely available as a welding gas. That will shield any reaction, if you can get it to do anything then you've stopped practicing chemistry and moved into physics...

You mentioned a lot of difficulty from oxidization while stirring. Would an inert gas atmosphere help?

I started experimenting with making ferrofluid a few years ago. Instead of using PCB etchant though, I just made an electrolytic cell with kosher salt solution and a wad of steel wool as the anode. I used a piece of copper pipe as a cathode, but I don't think the cathode material really matters. After a few minutes of electrolysis, the solution became basic, due to sodium reacting with water to produce hydroxide ions and hydrogen gas at the cathode, and what appeared to be iron (II) chloride began precipitating. Eventually, the steel wool fell apart so much that electrolysis almost ceased. At that point I dumped the liquid into a beaker, using a magnet to separate out all the particles of steel wool. I put the beaker on my stove and heated it. At a certain point, magnetite particles formed. It was obvious when this happened because the liquid turned black fairly abruptly.

I was able to confirm that the particles I produced were magnetite because I could stir the liquid, making it completely opaque, then hold a magnet to the side, which attracted all the particles, leaving behind a clear liquid. I intended to acquire some oleic acid and attempt to make a colloid, but then I moved and haven't really had space to experiment since. It would be interesting to see my experiment to completion. If quality magnetite could be produced with steel wool and salt, one could make a large quantity of ferrofluid very inexpensively.

Very nice video! I've been working with ferrofluids quite a while now, and use a very simple recipe to make highly concentrated water-based ferrofluids. I simply pour NH4OH in 15 seconds in a solution of FeCl2 and FeCl3 under manual stirring, stabilize with citric acid and wash several times with acetone using magnetic decantation. This is all done under atmospheric conditions in room temperature. You can check the details in our paper (just go to the section 2.2: Synthesis of water based magnetic fluids with electrostatic stabilization):
https://users.aalto.fi/~rras/publications/110.pdf

I have three recommendations for potentially increasing the consistency of your yield, and potentially the quality. The first idea is to use an inert gas to act as a shield against the oxygen in the atmosphere during mixing**. The second idea is to bring the original liquids up to a warmer temperature to get rid of as much dissolved oxygen as possible, and the third is to either change or regulate the temperature of the mixing portion, which could change the speed of the reaction and the size of the crystals that form.

*Full disclosure I have not tried these out, and they could do nothing, make it better, or make it worse.

**To create the inert gas layer you could put a plate over the top of it with a few holes in it. One of the holes would obviously be for the mixer rod, the other for the dropper, and the final one, (which could be combined with the second hole) would be to let in a stream of nitrogen, or some other inert gas to reduce oxidation. Unfortunately you wouldn't be able to seal everything because of moving parts. but it would go a long way towards reducing oxidation.

Or would it be possible to make a specially designed vacuum pump that was made to fit the exact set up?

Without oxygen, you wouldn’t have to worry about oxidation so you could make the stirring speed as fast as you want.

I once saw a documentary about the production of nanofluids. To control particle size they had something called a flow reactor: Basically a small tube (maybe even a capillary) which was mounted inside a bigger tube. Reactant A circulated freely trough the large tube, and reactant be was addes into the mixture against the current of reactant a trough the smaller tube. Apparently, they could control particle size very tightly simply by varying flow rate of reactant A and injection rate of reactant B. Can't find the documentary tough. This might be something you could look into tough. Seems like it would make for a much more controlled setup and eliminate your oxidation problems. Also, the setup is simple enough that you should be able to recreate it at home. I'll edit this post if I find that documentary or more info

Edit1: Just to be clear, I'm not talking about microfluidic continous flow reactors, altough these are also a very interesting topic on their own.
The system I'm talking about was macroscopic in scale

I have two theories for the batch that spiked really well.

1: Maybe you were keeping smaller particles than in other batches when you did the washings. You mentionned the preperation was almost the exact same, but it could be possible that the magnetite was washed a bit better and that it impacted the spike formation. The lack of bubbling from the surfactant would further support this theory.

2: Maybe the nanoparticles were smaller from increased mixing speed when you were making the magnetite. Maybe the mixing speed was just cranked up a bit quicker than in the previous runs.

In 1969 I dropped out of high school, doing poorly though once having been an A student. Chemistry completely flummoxed me, starting with the concept of the mole, and the idea of being able to calculate reactions. I had a poor teacher, and I had little respect for her. Fifty years and two college degrees later, I ran across a HS Chem lecture series by Frank Cardulla of Niles North HS in Skokie IL. It was thirty half-hour videos. He initially seemed to be a good teacher, and proved to be excellent as the series progressed. I worked my way through the first half, just enough to know that I could have done well at HS Chem had there been a teacher of his quality involved. Satisfied, I left chemistry behind once again, since at age 68 there was little need for HS chemistry in my daily life, but at least I can now follow along videos like these as a fan, if not a participant.

You said you bought a “nice” overhead mixer from Amazon. I found two that look like yours, a base model Onilab 20L at $400, and an improved model for over $1,100. I applaud you for putting your money where your hobby lies. I’m sure the mixer will have many future uses, but still, throwing down $400+ for the one tool needed to complete one project shows real dedication. I can't stop thinking about this video ever since I first saw it last month.
As a painter, I have so many questions.
What lightfastness does the ferrofluid have? (The lightfastness of paint is its resistance to UV exposure, most pigments become lighter with the passage of time, that's one of the reasons why old paintings seem brown and dull, the other being the fact that most oils and varnishes tend to darken with time.)
How does it cure on a gessoed surface?
Could you use linoleic acid instead of the oleic acid in order to permit it to cure to a thin film? (paints don't use oleic acid because it never cures, at least not in a useful way)
Or rather, to use linseed oil or safflower oil instead of the kerosene (because I see that the magnetite is quite dry powder)?
Could you use different materials instead of the magnetic iron compound? I'm thinking that coating each particle with the oil at a nano-level would increase the transparency and the flow of the pigments, I might be wrong tho. But if I'm not, it could spell a whole new age for oil painting, especially for the old-style paintings, like these that use multiple thin layers of paint to obtain depth and vivid colours (it's called glazing and because each layer contains only one colour and it's cured between applications, the pigments do not conflict with each other and thus are more intense, Vermeer and Leonardo dV used it, for example).
Currently, oil paints are made by straight-up mixing fine ground pigments with linseed oil or safflower oil and while the high-quality paints are really well mixed I doubt they could rival individual coating of pigment particles.

A few tips to solve your consistency are:
1. Use a 3 neck flask (5L is better).
2. Use a glass connector with a glass rod that fits, add grease to create a seal. Place in middle. Addition funnel at side.
3. Vacuum the whole system initially to remove oxygen trapped in the liquid, use a seal transfer adapter (attach to 3rd neck). Some ultrasonic cleaner at the bottom helps air removal.
4. Don't fully dry the particles, and use ultrasound to suspend them. Do "wash" with kerosene to remove water.
4a. Add kerosene to particles, agitate and suspend with ultrasound. Attach magnet to catch particles, decant liquid. Repeat 2 more times.

On a curious note, have you considered the following ideals in conjunction with your discoveries...

1) See the effects of food coloring to see if it would alter the color from black to whatever, or a combination of colors perhaps?

2) I noticed that it had a form of optical affect when you moved the magnet a particular distance from the magnetite, forming a bubble rather than spikes, could this have optical uses to increase our ability to see things far away

3) If you touch one of the spikes, is it sharp enough to penetrate the skin?  The liquid state gives it a "harmless" appearance.

4) How do electro-magnetic radio waves affect this.  Radio waves are a form of Electro-Magnetic radiation, of which is used in space for communication, since space doesn't have an atmosphere.  The electro-magnetic property itself, could have an interesting effect on this.  Perhaps another form of communication.

5) How does various light sources react upon this?  If we can't change how the eye work to see the world around us, which I am opposed to such things, I am however, curious as to whether we can effect such changes upon the magnetite itself to determine WHAT the eye see's on the other end.   How reflective it is, and can it be made transparent, to render something somewhat "invisible" ?

well done creating this product from scratch. In order to stop myself from completely dissecting this video i'll keep this short. The best way I see to get more consistent product is during the creating the Fe2+ is to be consistent with the amount used. From watching the video this seems to be the most inconsistent step. having a measured volume of fluid and mass of steel wool added will probably do most of the work for getting a better product. If you want to be more precise, with a bit of guessing you can determine the mass of the original iron chloride in the copper etchant by using a known volume of etchant and get the mass. Combine this with the composition you showed at 2:29 will get a decent approximation of how much FeCl3 there is and then how much steel wool to add, molarity, and etc.
During the stirring to create the Fe2+/Fe3+ mix, using a consistent way to increase the speed when running a batch could be helpful.
Lastly during the washing step, when you separate the magnetite into three separate beakers, if you were to measure the mass to be consistent and possibly do the same with the amount of water/alcohol added per rinse. Also use a stopwatch to be consistent with how long you let the iron settle.

p.s. maybe creating a small buffer solution to add to your ferrous chloride so you don't need to keep adding acid or add a bit of CO2 to store it under an inert atmosphere from some baking soda and vinegar.

Seeing the ferrofluids when you closed your eyes is actually a form of the tetris effect. The tetris effect is just the general phenomenon of familiarizing yourself with and repeating a task so often it begins to pattern your thoughts to that task. Usually it's induced by driving or repetitive work activities or video games, but considering how much you were focusing on the ferrofluid's shape and behavior it's not surprising you managed to induce the tetris effect.

Steel wool is coated with an oil to slow oxidation. This oil will inevitably become an impurity in any chemical reaction you do. But if you wash it in soap and rinse it off, you can remove the vast majority of it. Just make sure you don't leave it out as it will oxidize quickly.
Also: nitrogen, argon and CO2 is cheap at your local welding supply store. So you could consider mixing in a relatively oxygen free atmosphere simply by releasing the gas into the top of the beaker to replace the standard oxygen atmosphere and avoid most of the undesired reaction.

The atmospheric shielding need not be perfect, just enough that you can disregard the reaction.

For the isopropanol washes of the magnetite arent you worried that you actually loose highly magnetic (but very well coated) particles?
As you can know oleic acid does not interact with water very well, so the magnetite would precipitate out quite fast anyway, regardless of the magnet. But in the IPA wash however, the oleic acid coating likes to interact with the IPA solvent, therefore keeping the particles in suspension a lot better. And the reverse is also true, poorly coated particles will precipitate out rather easily from the IPA solution.
Wouldnt it be better to use the magnet for the water washes (selecting for magnetism) and to filter off the particles that remain in suspension for a longer time for the ipa wash (selecting for better coating and smaller particle size!)? Then you would have a small amount of highly magnetic, small, well-coated nanoparticles and a bigger batch of magnetic, bigger, less well coated particles.

Fantastic video! I've tried myself to make ferrofluid some times and failed miserably, and since you said that the agitation is so crucial to the project, could you also specify the impeller's size? From what I know, what usually really makes a difference when considering agitation is the reynold's number, that is related to the blade's rpm and diameter by (Re=density *nD²/viscosity), where n is the speed (rad/s) and D is the agitator diameter. Maintaining nD² the same when changing agitators should help maintain the process more realiable.

Have you considered mixing your magnetite under a blanket of CO2 (which might throw off the PH) N2 or better yet Argon? I am myself working on the measure and characterization of nanoparticles aggregation, so I have some questions and a suggestion. In my experience the nanoparticles starts to aggregate the moment they are formed and stirring greatly speed up the process: what happen to your reaction if you add the oleic acid before adding the ammonia? Another thing I noticed is that the reaction is much more reproducible and the nanoparticles are much smaller and uniform when the reagents are both as diluted as possible (the water is equally divided between the two solution): is it possible to tinker with the FeII-FeIII and ammonia solutions so that they have the same volume? Maybe instead of starting with a beaker full of water, use only half the amount and add the other half to the ammonia

The last thing I want to mention is that when you washed your particles using the magnet to filter the good from the bad, you are actually discarding the smallest ones: this is because the smallest nanoparticles remain suspended for a much longer time. In addition, if my memory serves me well, the magnetic force decrease with the cube of the distance, so the particles in the top part of the beaker are not affected by the magnet.

In the past I have done research on magnetite nanoparticle quality vs. how you mix the iron salts with ammonia (or other bases), and which concentrations to use. The issue with your method is that the ammonia is mixed into the iron salts slowly, which causes two problems: 1. The growth of particles happens slowly over the course of several minutes which is ideal for growing large crystals instead of nanoparticles. 2. The particles that are formed in the beginning of the reaction is formed inside a liquid with a different concentration and pH than the particles that are formed later (concentration varies during the course of the ammonia addition), hence you will end up with a larger variation in particle size and morphology.

The best way to make magnetite nanoparticles (that I know of) is to use a T-mixer type of mixing method, where the two liquids (Iron salt mixture and ammonia) is simultaneously and at the same rate pushed/flowed into a T or Y crossing, so that they instantly mix under high speed, and importantly, the resultant liquid and particles flows away into a separate channel and container where they never come in contact with unreacted ammonia or iron salt, this prevents additional particle growth from occurring.

Here is a short paper explaining such a method written by some colleagues of mine. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237842518_Rapid_mixing_A_route_to_synthesize_magnetite_nanoparticles_with_high_moment

I have got some experience with nanoparticle syntheses. The size of the magnetite will greatly determine the properties of the ferro fluid. So I suspect the setup you are using causes the lack of reproducibility between batches. Indeed faster stirring will introduce more oxygen into solution, but you can counter that by purging the solution with N2 gas during synthesis. Furthermore, an addition funnel is not a reliable way of adding a chemical if the addition speed is a key parameter. It might be better to use a syringe pump to control the addition speed of the base. Lastly, instead of adding the base in a dropwise manner, you can also slowly inject it into solution. This will limit local pH differences at the solution-air interface which could increase the reproducibility. Anyway, these are just some of my thoughts on the synthesis procedure. Keep up the good work!!
